Posts.Content: Feb 13, 2009 07:45AM car wrote: I'm waiting to be scheduled for a tattoo and have a 2" long football shaped scar which has already faded a good deal (flap surgery was 4/08). I'm very happy w/the result--even pre-tattoo.
Posts.Title: DIEP Surgeries BessB BessB

Posts.Content: Feb 13, 2009 06:25PM car wrote: Bess, I think you should be upfront w/these concerns w/your PS. You might be surprised at what s/he is willing to discuss w/you in terms of options. To me, it doesn't matter, especially as I've got the shape I want and there's another scar leading toward my ribs where he took out some tissue for symmetry. I went into the DIEP surgery w/horribly large and encapsulated implants and he had to sort of guess what my normal size would be--especially w/the cancer-related weight loss. I preferred to have tissue removed and an add'l scar to be even on both sides (perfect 32B!) w/out implants.
Posts.Title: DIEP Surgeries BessB BessB

Posts.Content: Feb 19, 2009 07:53PM - edited Feb 19, 2009 07:54PM by car Let me say from the git-go that I'm still angry about my implants which encapsulated immediately. As for cause, from what I've read in the medical literature, capsulation is about 30-50% among BC pts., much higher than cosmetic pts. Much of that is due to the tissue changes due to rads. On the other hand, encapsulating is "independent of surgical skill" from what I've been reading and what the medical literature terms as "idiopathic" (rough translation, depends on the pt. and a major medical "go figure"). My first PS (I gave up and went to another for DIEP) recommended massage after the exchange, then put me on Accolate to try to reduce the encapsulation. Neither worked. In the interest of full disclosure I have a crappy immune system due to chronic allergies and asthma. To me, my body responded to the implants like a foreign body. My original PS said that there's "anecdotal evidence" to support that but nothing in the medical literature (and I've also done that search).  This is just my $.02, but from your post your biggest risk is your rads. Heavy lifting will possibly increase your risk of lymphedema if you had any nodes removed, but nothing on your list should increase the risk of encapsulation from my experience or reading. I'm very physically active, but my encapsulation started before I had been released to exercise.
Posts.Title: lets talk implant capsulating?? joanne2 joanne2

Posts.Content: Feb 20, 2009 11:19AM car wrote: Joanne, you sound like you're doing well for 4 weeks out. I'd 2nd that suggestion about light weights or isometrics. Actually, I've done Pilates for years and that has done wonders to help w/my range of motion and any residual scar tissue. My PS concurs and also suggests yoga, but my mind's too busy for yoga. Thanks for the compliment on my wonderful dog. He's older and slower now, and actually has a ca diagnosis himself, but at least that waited until my act was pulled together. He's my best friend. We see his onc on Tuesday.

Posts.Content: Dec 24, 2010 02:16PM - edited Aug 20, 2013 03:28AM by car Hi--after a long absence. I'm in the same situation (or close to it) and trying not to freak out. Friends and family are in the "you're so strong" phase. Anyway, I'm still healing from a stereotactic biopsy that tested positive for ADH--which had been a precursor of my DCIS for which I had a mammo/recon in 2007. MRI is scheduled for Wednesday, and I should know the results of that w/in a couple of days. I'm wondering what folks in this situation were advised (yes, I'm playing the guessing game for the holidays). Wait and see if the ADH moves to DCIS? Tamoxifen? Surgery w/or w/out rads? I will say that I'm at Hoag in Newport Beach w/an excellent team. My appt. w/my onc is scheduled for the 2nd week of January unless he moves it up. My onc and I agreed that I would not take tamoxifen after my mx. Unless he (not my surgeon) convinces me otherwise, my gut feeling is to continue to reject tamoxifen. I honestly think that I'd prefer additional surgery than to tolerate the side effects.

Posts.Title: URGENT help needed - implant removal. Should I get both out? Suze Suze

Posts.Content: Jan 2, 2009 11:21AM car wrote: I couldn't wait to get rid of my implant (unilateral) mx and the augmentation necessary for a match. The capsular contraction was so bad I told my onc that I was at the point where I wanted to rip them out w/my fingernails (he cautioned against what he called psychic surgery). My onc referred me to a wonderful PS for a flap procedure. I've just finished stage II of a DIEP and feel fantastic. I'm comfortable w/my body and my friends say I look like my old self. DIEP is the standard recon procedure in Sweden. Here--you have to seek out a very experienced surgeon. I think it's well worth it. I'd be happy if anyone wanted to PM about this or post more.
Posts.Title: URGENT help needed - implant removal. Should I get both out? Suze Suze

Posts.Content: Jan 2, 2009 06:16PM car wrote: Suze, I'm so sorry about that. I didn't realize where you were located. I would be very cautious about the DIEP failure rates--which are quite high w/inexperienced surgeons. I read an article that cited a "learning curve" of 50 surgeries (or women's breasts, depending on your sensitivity. My only suggestion would be to travel, or google your local universities. If you're unhappy w/your PS can your onc provide a referral? If Belgium is an option, I know that Blondeel has done a lot of DIEPs and published in that area. He's in Ghent.

Posts.Content: Dec 11, 2008 12:11PM car wrote: I agree w/Penny. I felt like crap during treatment, but rather than considering myself sick once I got the phone call re my dx I felt anxious and angry. I knew that I wouldn't die, but was more concerned about how much of a hit my body would take.
Posts.Title: Do you consider yourself sick? shockedat39 kmccraw423

Posts.Content: Dec 20, 2008 09:00PM car wrote: No worries. DCIS is so darned complicated. I was so relieved when I got the Stage 0 diagnosis and I thought wham-bang, wire localization, lumpectomy, and radiation. In one sense, if you're going to get BC DCIS is your best case scenario. On the other hand, for such a "low-grade" cancer to be treatable w/a mastectomy (my own case) is mind boggling. I wish the best for your mom. There are lots of options for reconstruction, too. I couldn't have gone through a unilateral mastectomy w/out a reconstruction. And a mastectomy isn't the worst thing to live through. All the best.
Posts.Title: My mom has DCIS...should we consider ourselves lucky? stoor PuddinTame

Posts.Content: Dec 20, 2008 09:11PM - edited Dec 20, 2008 09:12PM by car No, I'm not. I had hoped for a lumpectomy but one of the problems w/DCIS is that it can be "multifocal," that is, spread throughout the breast. I was fighting a mastectomy like crazy. First, my surgeon showed me what I'd be left w/after a lumpectomy (I'm a 32B, and it was about half of my breast). Then, when he read the pathology report to me, I was sure that mastectomy was the answer. Not only was it throughout the ducts (they're very, very, small and radiate through the breast) but the path report indicated DCIS in a "buckshot pattern." There is no way that they could have gotten all of it w/out a mastectomy. There are some that say that DCIS might never turn into invasive cancer, but I was unwilling to take that chance. I hated having the mastectomy, but now that I've got an excellent recon (DIEP flap) it's not that big of a deal. I certanly didn't want to risk my life over a breast. Do pass along this site to your mom. She also can contact me if she wishes.
Posts.Title: My mom has DCIS...should we consider ourselves lucky? stoor PuddinTame

Posts.Content: Jan 8, 2009 09:55PM car wrote: Hey, shabby. First of all, wait until you have your biopsy results before freaking out. I completely understand that you're overwhelmed right now--rightly so. I had a DCIS dx and was able to deal w/dx and treatment over 4-5 months. Whether or not that is your dx, you'll find that you can deal with it. It's not a walk in the park, but you can survive DCIS. My dx was DCIS in my left breast. I fought hard for a lumpectomy and radiation, but it was so diffused throughout my breast I had to have a mastectomy. That said, it wasn't the end of the world. You have a lot of options w/mastectomies--if it comes down to that. My reconstruction was started at the time of the mastectomy, and though it took much longer than anticipated, I'm really feeling good, look good, and am cancer free 2 years down the road. Feel free to send a PM. You're overwhelmed w/family issues right now, but you need to take care of yourself. Cancer does indeed suck, but if I were to choose over breast cancer dx, I'd still  jump at DCIS. Take good care.
Posts.Title: Can't stop reading "stats" on web. In bad shape... shabby6485 Member_of_the_Club

Posts.Content: Dec 22, 2008 10:50PM car wrote: Carolyn, I'm so sorry that you'll have to have a mastectomy. That's the thing about DCIS that sucks. Thought the prognosis is good, the treatment often is mastectomy. Has your surgeon spoken w/you about reconstruction? If you're considering reconstruction, it's best to have the plastic surgeon invovled w/the mastectomy. My DCIS was less well differentiated, but on the positive side, I've had no chemo, radiation, or medication such as tamoxifen. I hated the thought of a mastectomy, but it wasn't the end of the world. Be up front w/your surgeon now if you're considering reconstruction. There are a lot of options: www.breastreconstruction.org.
Posts.Title: Just Diagnosed with Cancer Carolyn2008 Carolyn2008

Posts.Content: Dec 23, 2008 08:12PM car wrote: I don't think that it's the end of the world if you don't have immediate reconstruction. I had my first PS in the OR when an expander was placed to replace the breast tissue. I went through the fill process, and then implants 6 months later. That reconstruction was a failure (I encapsulated immediately) and I underwent a 2nd reconstruction (DIEP) which involved a different incision and excision of the implants. As for waiting, if it's DCIS you do have some time (unless your surgeon does feel that it's very aggressive). My original dx was in August, I went through numerous opinions before I found the BS at Hoag that I felt comfortable with and didn't get in to see him and then get the MRI until November. He gave me the option of quickly scheduling a surgery before the New Year or waiting until after the holidays. My mx was 1/17/07--quite a while after diagnosis. I would not, repeat not, go w/a PS who has not done a lot of reconstructions. My original PS was one of the best in the area and it was a disaster. My DIEP required a very, very experienced surgeon and I waited months to get on his calendar. And was he ever worth it. Feel free to PM, too, if you're worried. Take good care.
Posts.Title: Just Diagnosed with Cancer Carolyn2008 Carolyn2008

Posts.Content: Dec 26, 2008 01:18PM car wrote: Moody, my 2nd recon is a resounding success. I had DIEP recon and about 4 weeks ago had the scar "revised" (it bothered my PS more than me) and the foob reduced to match cup size as well as a lift to finish off the match. I just got back from Christmas at my sister's and wore a shelf bra camisole. Neither she nor her partner could remember which side the mx was on. I have a little hematoma that's going away and I'm on silicone sheets, but ready to hit the sales because it looks as if I'm done (except for the tattoo). I highly recommend DIEP.
Posts.Title: Just Diagnosed with Cancer Carolyn2008 Carolyn2008

Posts.Content: Jan 8, 2009 11:39PM - edited Jan 8, 2009 11:44PM by car Thanks, kateful for the back up. I'm lucky. I was able to work around my teaching schedule at the university and drive between LA and Orange Counties in So. Cal. for my tests and opinions. That gives you a lot of strength--information is power. My dean also gave me a semester off (there's no such things as subs at a univeristy) and the checks kept coming. So that helped tremendiously. The treatment after all of my research and consults was a no brainer. What is more difficult is the choice of reconstruction--if you decide to go that route. Had I been bilateral, I might not have. After a horrible experience w/implants, I'm very pleased w/my DIEP. I really feel back to normal, especially since my bra size has stabilized and I can buy some normal clothes. Oh, and the stats? The latest article I pulled up on Medline indicates that I have a cumulative risk of 0.4% per year for a recurrence, though I'm double the risk of a new cancer on the other side (11% to 22%). That said, I can live w/those odds especially since I have a wonderful oncologist who is encouraging lifestyle management rather than tamoxifen. If I live to my mid-90s you're talking about a 20% chance of recurrence or new cancer w/out treatment w/tamoxifen, and my exericse and diet regimen reduces that risk substantially.  I think that I'm going to be around for quite a while annoying my students. All the best.
Posts.Title: Can't stop reading "stats" on web. In bad shape... shabby6485 Member_of_the_Club

Posts.Content: Jan 4, 2009 11:50PM - edited Jan 4, 2009 11:51PM by car A recliner or pillows on both sides are a big help. I tend to be a back sleeper but found that I'd roll to the side duirng the night. I could sleep in a recliner or on my back in bed w/bolsters of pillows alongside. I wasn't able to lie on my chest for months.
Posts.Title: Hello from a NEW member! elizzim elizzim

Posts.Content: Jan 1, 2009 08:07PM - edited Jan 1, 2009 08:08PM by car rubybuttons, I live alone and my sister took care of me for a couple of weeks. All I could do was sit in a recliner. I couldn't even make my bed. If you can cover it financially, you might help your mother-in-love out (I love that) w/someone to come in and do the housecleaning. You'll probably be able to manage the drains by yourself after the hospital staff trains you (I don't know why I was so worried about drains because they're not that big of a deal), but lifting, laundry, washing dishes, cooking, are out of the picture in your case. You'll also need a driver for appts. roseg's suggestion for yeast meds is a good one. My GYN suggested a 7-day course of Monistat suppositories (they seem to be easier to deal with and tolerate) every time I had surgery and antibiotics. That has been indispensable to me (5 surgeries this year, including oral surgeries). I don't know how old you are, but these sort of infections increase during perimenopause, and I now just grab Monistat-7 when I'm going in for "work." Family is indispensable. Give her a big hug (and gift when appropriate)!

I did check into Loma Linda, but wasn't thrilled about the options available and they're notoriously bad about waits. The BS I consulted w/locally said that the skin-sparring mx that I wanted and recon just wasn't available in the IE and I should go to Hoag in Newport or City of Hope (I think that's Duarte). I've been very happy w/Dr. Lincoln Snyder at Hoag for my BS and Dr. Neil Barth (also Hoag) for oncology. As for my recon...UCLA! I have PPO and am very happy w/my treatment.
Posts.Title: Looking for a BS in Inland Empire of California Dustysmom car

Posts.Content: Mar 4, 2009 07:02PM - edited Mar 4, 2009 07:06PM by car Nikki--I think that you're making the right choice. You are not the first woman w/ADH to whom tamoxifen has been suggested. The research has only assessed its effectiveness w/women w/DCIS and higher grades of cancer. That's more of an onc's judgment call than a surgeon. And, BTW, my onc and I decided not to go w/the Tamoxifen. You're not paranoid--you're vigilant. You'll be amazed at the technology at the MD's fingertips at Hoag. It really is worth the drive. And again, feel free to PM. Cheryl R.
Posts.Title: Looking for a BS in Inland Empire of California Dustysmom car

Posts.Content: Mar 3, 2009 07:44PM - edited Mar 3, 2009 10:11PM by car Dustysmom--another plug for Dr. Snyder at Hoag. From where I am  it's less than an hour's drive.I was very unhappy w/the diagnostics here in town w/my ADH dx and still having to wait 6 weeks for a stereotactic biopsy and then Redlands Community wanting me to return for the 2nd spot. I flat out refused to leave the table and told them to keep going. Hoag's comprehensive breast care center has available right there ultrasound, MRI, digital mammograms, etc. I've never gone back to my MDs in town since my experience at Hoag. My DCIS was found 6 months via stereotactic biopsy after my ADH dx--not to scare you, but to emphasize the importance of vigilance and high quality care. Dr. Snyder now performs my annual mammos and either he or my onc orders an MRI either every year or every other year, depending on how things are going. I get all of my breast care out there, though I still get an annual w/my family practice guy here. Another thing about Dr. Snyder is that he is very, very good about discussing options especially in cases like ADH and DCIS that are very complicated. Feel free to PM if you'd like.Frankly, w/PPO I won't deal w/treatment in the IE for this.
Posts.Title: Looking for a BS in Inland Empire of California Dustysmom car

Posts.Content: Dec 30, 2008 03:59PM - edited Dec 30, 2008 03:59PM by car At least in my case, I've found that the effects of anesthesia are very long lasting. I've "gone under" 5 times this year, if you count oral surgery, and each time it takes a while to come back. Most of my fatigue postop is cognitive--which means I'm way behind schedule on the book I'm supposed to be working on at home. Fortunately, I'm not teaching this year due to sabbatical and I have an understanding editor. Still, there are days when I just can't work.

Posts.Content: Jan 2, 2009 09:53AM car wrote: I forgot about the steps! In the hospital ask if you can see a PT. She taught me how to negotiate stairs. What you need to do is to face the bannister, grasp it w/two hands and step sideways up, place the 2nd foot next to the 1st on the same step, step sideways up, place the 2nd foot next to the 1st. Hope this makes sense--but ask if you can get some PT.
Posts.Title: Back home - what will I need help with? ghety ghety

Posts.Content: Jan 2, 2009 06:04PM car wrote: Nor I! The bottom line is to always have 2 feet on the step before proceeding to the next. Good luck!
Posts.Title: Back home - what will I need help with? ghety ghety

Posts.Content: Dec 24, 2008 07:34PM car wrote: I've been following this thread though I opted for reconstruction immediately upon dx. My decision might be different if my cancer were more aggressive and if it were bilateral. As I told a friend of mine, I just couldn't go w/the "Amazon look" and I have a low risk of recurrence. I did get pushed toward saline implants at first--I had researched the BS and the comprehensive cancer center thoroughly, and though the PS was well recommended by the BS and the RNs (always listen to the RNs), it failed. I have been delighted w/my DIEP reconstruction, though I had it a year later due to work obligations. If I do have a recurrence, I'll have an autologous reconstruction in a heartbeat. That said, had the cancer been diagnosed in both breasts, I might very well have opted for no reconstruction.
